prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I sent a screenshot of my “friend” making fun of my girlfriend who has chemo to his mom?
(M 18) I was in a group chat with a bunch of friends and we were talking about the upcoming lacrosse season. All of a sudden out of nowhere my friend goes, “Why do you sound like such a bitch?”. I thought he was just messing around and I said “Why don’t you hit up the gym and get your weight up?” Because he’s short and skinny. He responded with, “That’s why I’m gonna fuck your 400 pound fatass girlfriend”. 

My jaw hit the floor, my girlfriend has been going through chemo since December and is currently swollen and bloated because her kidneys aren’t working properly. Her lupus was so bad that she was a day away from dying. (Her swelling made her go from 108-170 btw)

I told him that he went way too far and he just said, “Don’t talk shit then”. He’s obviously has no remorse for what he says and I don’t know what to do or say. 

I know it might be a shitty thing to do but I’m not trying to escalate things in front of my other friends, they dont really know what to do and they haven’t taken any side yet. 

We all help this kid hide shit from his parents all the time. I know it might not be the most moral thing to do but he’s making my blood boil and it’s either that or I say something about his real dad leaving him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

Sending the screenshot to the friend's mom could be seen as a form of seeking accountability, especially since the friend showed no remorse and the author felt that other friends were not supporting them. 

On the other hand, the author is bypassing the friend and involving his mother, which might be considered a betrayal of trust or an invasion of privacy. However, considering the severity of the comments and the friend's lack of empathy, some might argue that the author had a right to act to protect their partner and hold the friend accountable.

The key factors here are the intent behind the action and the context. The author's intent was to address hurtful behavior that their partner is going through a tough time, and the friend's refusal to acknowledge wrongdoing. The method of confrontation might be questionable, but the underlying issue is the friend's harmful behavior. 

In such cases, people often debate between privacy and accountability. While sending messages to a parent isn't the usual approach, the circumstances are extreme. The author might not be in the wrong because they were trying to prevent further harm, especially given the friend's dismissive attitude. However, there's a valid argument about the appropriateness of the method. 

But considering the severity of the friend's comments and the lack of remorse, the author's action could be seen as a justified attempt to address the issue when other methods failed. So, the answer leans towards B (the author is not in the wrong).
